bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, March 9, 1890

div1.p: Carter writes that he has returned home, but has contracted malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, March 9, 1890
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of ..........................., Surgeon's Office,
Sunday, March 9, 1890.
Dear Ma:
div1.p:
I had no trouble at all coming back until I
reached Atlanta from there down the heat was dry &
disagreeable, but except for being tired I was well
Sunday night; woke up with a dull headache &
could eat no breakfast, but felt fairly strong & the
head got well, If I had gone to bed at the
hotel in Biloxi & stayed 24 hours, with & doctored
myself, it might have been all right, I didn't
but went aboard the Annie & started out. The wind
had been fair &but hauled dead ahead in
about 35 minutes & we reached our anchor-
age out side of Chandeleur - because we c'd
not see to go in at 2 A. M. MondayTuesday. I began to
feel sick about 2.30 P. M, Monday & my head-
ached so that I could not lie down & I sat
up in one corner of the cabin until nearly
day when I fell asleep. It was cold also. Next
morning, the tide being low, I was rowed
ashore in a small boat 4 miles & went
straight to bed, & I was pretty sick. Pains
of all kinds & descriptions, Fever, vomiting & gener-
al malaise. Yesterday afternoon was the first time
I put on my breeches to sit up, & until Thursday Fri
Friday I didcould not even have the letter mail
read to me, I think I was malarial & the grip &
the fatigue developed it. Indeed I know
it. I was pretty sick for 2 days, & am no good
yet.

In addition, I directed my clothes fumiga-
ted & all went in - I was too sick to think - & my over-
coat will have to be dyed & the other one looks
decidedly queer but is wearable

Just Found the station in a fuss & as soon as I can
travel must go to Scranton - about 20 miles from
Biloxi, to see a ship carpenter a trip I dread-
at least the part from herethis place to Biloxi. It has
been, & is, rather a serious time with me.

Laura had fixed up your room & had
had the house fumigated to kill the
roaches & mice for you & they all were disap-
pointed. Henry has been having boils, but
I hope will have no more. Edward seems to
have charge of the house & weeps bitterly
when I don't follow when he attempts to
lead me. He has found out now that I can't
& doesn't mind so much. Was especially hurt at my
not going to see the chickens of which he has 11
- baby chickens- The two Lauras are well.

All the men save one whom, as I was sick, I was
afraid to send are at Biloxi & Ship Island
with the barges & will not be back un-
til near the end of the week.
Enter Edward; who wants the ink.
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate Son H. R. Carter March 12/90
getting better steadily & not so slowly either, Hen-
ry was espicially disappointed by you
not coming & even Ed says “Gamma”. Al
though without much knowledge of what it
means I suppose, only he thinks he should
be rewarded by a pen & ink for so doing,
I am sorry I could not see Hill & his people
but it certainly was a visit which directed
it self without any aid from me & against
all of my plans.
I read the “Counsel of Perfection” on the train. It is, as a work
of art, perfect. He took With almost no use of incident
a very pleasant satisfactory book is produced. Not
one
thing
in it which
could have been
left out, not one thing
omitted which sh'd have been put it. The beginning, progress
& end are perfect. There is no waste in it & nothing under-
or over drawn.
H. R. Carter
